title: Are Iraqis ethnically Arab or culturally? - Quora

response.answer_text: The overwhelming majority of Iraqis are Muslim Arabs and the state was designed to be uninclusive of minorities (save for minimal periods where Muslim Kurds were theoretically equalized). An ethnicity encompasses identity, religion/values, language, culture, and genetics, so I’ll give a brief here. Iraq was founded and/or has consisted of the following populations since created by Britain in the early 20th century: Christians ArmeniansAssyrians (also known as Arameans, Chaldeans, and Syriacs)Jews Shia Muslims Arabs (Afro, Bedouin, Central/Marsh/Southern “non-Bedouin”)Feylis (Iranians)Shabaks (Iranians)Persians (Iranians)Turkmen (Turks)Sunni Muslims Arabs (Afro, Bedouin, North “non-Bedouin”, Palestinian)Caucasians (Chechens, Circassians)Kurds (Kurmanji, Sorani)Non-Abrahamic MandeansYezidisFrom this list, only Assyrians, Mandeans, and Mesopotamian Jews can claim clear descent and continuity from Mesopotamian culture. Why? Assyrians, Jews, & Mandeans practice(d) pre-Islamic religions and most maintained their Sumero-Akkadian influenced Aramaic languages that had developed under the Assyrian Empire even under the extreme arabization policies of Iraq.Arabic-speaking Assyrians & Jews historically spoke [North] Mesopotamian Arabic, which is distinct from Iraqi Arabic. Iraqi Arabic is influenced by Iranic languages and [Syrian] Bedouin & Gulf Arabic dialects, while Mesopotamian is influenced by Assyrian [Aramaic] like the North Levantine & Cypriot Arabic dialects. [Muslim] Baghdadi Arabic goes a step further in being Bedouin-derived.The genetics of these three groups is similar, while those of Iraqi Arabs resemble that of a hybrid Iranian/Arabian population with other influences (Arabs are not genetically homogenous, much like Kurds & Turks, as seen with my inclusion of Afro-Iraqi Arabs).In summation, Iraqis are Arabs. Their identity is only related to these three groups because of cohabitation in a modern country. Today, most Assyrians, Mandeans, and Mesopotamian Jews live in other lands, cohabiting with other foreign populations precisely because they were non-Muslims and non-Arabs, thus were ethnically cleansed, and in the case of Assyrians, also experienced physical genocide. Dialects: Dark Blue - Mesopotamian Arabic Red - Iraqi Arabic Magenta - Gulf Arabic Green, Dark Green, Cyan - Bedouin Arabic Yellow - Kurdish

I am from Iraq but not Arabic. That already can answer much. Ethnically it’s mixed, culturally it’s mixed. When we talk about Arabic culture, it’s actually the Arabic gulf culture. A real Arabic culture is what you see in Saudi Arabia . Iraq is a very new country, not even 100 years old. It was not an Arabic country in origin. It was invaded by Arabs in the time of Islamic expansion. Even after that, it was very much influenced by Persian culture and scientists. All the so called Arabic scientists that make Baghdad one of the science centers in the history, and make Abbasi age a golden age, were Persian, or coming from nations under Persian empire. This history made Arabic culture very weak in Iraq, especially in middle and north, where it’s away from gulf. Another fact is the diversity of culture and ethnicity in Iraq. The two major ones are Arabs and Kurds, but there are other minorities too. This all makes Iraq a mixture with each one affecting the other. So in conclusion; Iraq is not Arabic. It’s a Middle East country with Arabs being majority.

Not all Iraqis. The majority of Iraqis today are “Arab” (mostly Shia, with some Sunni). However, the indigenous people of Northern Iraq are the Assyrians (Church of the East, Chaldean, Evangelical, and Syriac churches) who primarily speak various dialects of Neo-Aramaic. The Marsh Arabs and many of the Muslim Arabs of Iraq are Arabized/Islamized Assyrians, Jews, etc. In the north as well, there are Kurds (both Sunni and Shia) who were originally mostly from Northern Iran. Shabaks who are mixed ethnically. There are Turkmen Turks who are also known as “Turcoman” in the north. Yazidis who are of mixed Assyrian and Kurdish ancestry. There are and were also Armenians and Jews in Iraq. As you can see, Iraq is actually VERY ethnically and religiously diverse. It is an “Arab” country only because the majority of the population is Arabic-speaking. There are many languages spoken in Iraq other than Arabic. The primary ones are Arabic, Kurdish, Iraqi Turkmen, and Neo-Aramaic.

Iraq is an Arab country. Culturally, linguistically, It’s Arab. Ethnically, well lots of Arab tribes settled down to make up for slaughter of Arabized-Arab populations by Mongols and Turks but there were still some left who married with incoming Arabian tribes. People of mixed Arab-Arabized origin make up the majority of Iraqis, Sunni and Shia. 20% are non-Arab though, including most notably Kurds, but also Turks, Assyrians, Chaldeans, Armenians, and Persians. Also, its worth pointing out that Sunni Kurds and Shia Persians historically intermarried with Sunni and Shia Arabs in the cities. And many Kurdish and Persian families in Mosul, Baghdad and Najaf assimilated and became Arabized. And Arabic was historically the language of high culture regardless of ethnic origin. It’s historically one of the most cosmopolitan and diverse of Arab countries.

I'm not really sure about that , alot Iraqis belongs to Arabian tribes however that doesn't mean they are Arabians , i know an Iraqi girl from the Arabian tribe of Shammar , she was barely 0.6% Arabian (or 6% I don't really remember) I guess many Iraqis are assimilated to these Tribes , my father for example had two completely different tribes , however there are Iraqis who are from these tribes Many Iraqis calls themselves musawai and claims they are from Imam Musa Bin Jafar , it's funny because Musa Bin Jafar was said to be very dark skinned (black) Iraqis society is both tribal and not tribal.

It's both. Now ethnicically speaking Iraq is diverse not all of them are Arabians they have other minorities such as Kurds, turkmens and assyrians. However the vast majority of Iraqis are Arabs and many belong to ancient tribes. Culturally speaking, Arabic culture has the most powerful impact on Iraq, which is normal since the majority are and they even developed their own that it became a common Iraqi culture for all the Iraqis not only Arabians.

mostly culturally arab but a good large portion of Iraq’s “arab population” are semitic but not arab and would instead descend from Assyrians, Chaldeans, Sumerians and others. My iraqi ex girlfriend calls herself arab but we both think she is either sumerian *(what she said)* or babylonian *(what I say)* based on her phenotype but we both just call her an arab. Ethnic arabs who’s ancestral roots and dna traced to arabia peninsula exists in iraq all over. They are called Arab tribals. But tribal arabs are rare. Again most Iraqis are Arabized mesopotamian semites.

Iraq is a large formation of cultures and nationalities, the largest part of them Arabs and the origin of the Arabs are from the Arabian Peninsula and Yemen, the Arabs are in Iraq of the tribes most of the origins of these tribes are from the Arabian Peninsula, which migrated to Iraq before the BC So the Arab tribes spread not in Iraq only, but in many of the neighboring countries of the Arabian Peninsula and Yemen, so we see many of the neighboring countries of the Arabian Peninsula and Yemen, for example in the Levant, Egypt, Africa and others were migrated because of trade or to seek knowledge or to spread the religion of Islam

Arabs from Iraq are Arab in all senses (culture, language, and ethnicity). They would mostly descend from Arab civilizations and tribes that were in Mesopotamia such as: Arab presence in Ancient BabylonKingdom of OsroeneLakhmidsBanu Kalb (بنو كلب)Muslim Arab tribes (especially descendants of Muhammad and his family)As you can see, Arabs have had a presence in Oraq for a bet long time and anyone who is Arab from Iraq is an ethnic Arab, not Arabized.
Iraqis are both. There are Iraqis who are ethically Arabs and there are Arabized Iraqis. Iraq also have other minorities such as Assyrians, Kurds , Turkmans etc etc.
most culturally arab some ethnically so modern republic of iraq includes all Mesopotamia and large swaths of desert (and it’s ethnic arab people) that aren’t part of Mesopotamia
arabs invade and colonize many centuries ago, but they did not mix with the native people like assyrians and chaldeans, arabs are the majority in Iraq.
The Bedouins are ethnically Arab.The non-tribal Arabs are culturally Arab they are descended from Assyrians,Babylonians and Sumerians who converted to Islam and became Arabized.
